Date: 29. Mai 2016 um 12:03:19 MESZ Subject: Russian President Vladimir Putin Threatens NATO - Australia Network News Q: What relevance has Putin's recent NATO threats to conducting a navel exercise in W. hemisphere w/ a Central or S. American country b/f 1/7/16: A. On the one hand, the quick response is none.  However, although the attached note does NOT address the above mentioned Q, a more nuanced, considered judgement is: it DOES provide more circumstantial evidence of Russian primary geopolitical military focus and, engagement. http://www.australianetworknews.com/russian-president-vladimir-putin-threatens-nato/
"...Russian President Vladimir Putin has made it clear today that his country will be responding against the recent US move of deploying a ground-based missile defense system in Romania...Putin threatened NATO during a news conference held in Athens after he met with Greek Prime Minister Aleksis Tsipras. He is in Greece in what is widely viewed as a visit to mend damaged relationship with the European Union..." Comment: W/ thirty two (32) days left to resolution of this forecast, CAVEAT NB to myself 8/5/16 forecast. Same rationale there applies here.  NB: Attempting to forecast a Putin move is fraught w/ high probability risks. Not to mention the Brier Score forecast of 0 effects of a "gummy boat exercise w/ a Mexican/Caribbean Country" before 1/7/16! Game over for me, unfortunately.  This said, the recent NATO threat keeps Putin where he strategically has placed himself over the past six months - on the political stage.  A gummy boat exercise w/ an above mentioned Country is possible but, would argue here, considering the totality to his recent actions & MACHO manner, such a peanuts exercise makes him look a little foolish. For a full blooded flotilla exercise in this region of the world he has no additional time. The funds used for such a show are better spent elsewhere.  In the Middle East (ME) an increasingly clear pivot towards a "leveraged ME influence" in Syria has left Russia better off today on future negotiations than it was six months ago.   Additionally, Russian OPEC interests in the region, including Iran & other Gulf Countries, will require continued focus. Putin's  pivot towards the Far East w/ China & Japan show his clear objective in achieving a disharmony b/w G7 members ( PM Abe & Putin efforts @ improving relations over dispute islands issue). Abe's visit to Sochi. And, much "discussion" of a Putin visit to Japan "later" this year?

GJ Q resolved 1/7/16: 
Slightly more than 50 days to go before resolution of this GJ Q 1/7/16.
I have been below consensus since March &, take my 1% forecast to 0. Here is why. As @Khalid recently reiterated, "almost certainly not". And, I am certainly mindful of @clinton *low bar* trigger event such as a small anti narcosis navel exercise as well. So, it's always a possibility.  That said, from a top down perspective ( outside view if you like)  Putin's focus continues to be on improving his G7 standing &, achieving support to get Russia out of the sanctions doghouse and, have the UN back off its multifaceted sanctions regime.  His recent meeting w/ PM Abe of Japan in Sochi, Russia is one example of Putin's strategic objective to keep himself on an international stage ( albeit - this being an island dispute). Importantly, Abe has essentially turned down an Obama recommendation not to visit w/ Putin w/ the recent Sochi meeting. Correctly, Abe has every right to consider his domestic interests. On the other hand, Putin clearly calculated such an event some time ago and, is clearly motivated to show the West he is flexible when Russian interests are aided. More importantly, should the Russians take on such an exercise in the Western Hemisphere w/ a Central or S. American country b/f 1/7/16, the event would put Putin in a detrimental/negative light on his serious effort @ receiving an official invitation from Abe to Japan at some point this year to find a resolution of the islands issue. Abe has already his interest in doing so while not being specific a date.  Much to the contrary. There is a high probability ( >75%) Putin has a vested interest in avoiding any "blow back"  on Abe ...from other G7 member countries during this phase... to assure Putin's strategically more critical objective: showing a potential break between G7 members on how to deal with Russia. Such a navel exercise, when considering the above mentioned, over the time line of this questions looks to be a 0 probability. CAVEAT: to myself: remember @clinton on his point

http://www.familysecuritymatters.org/publications/detail/russian-naval-expansion-threatens-us-influence-in-the-western-hemisphere?f=must_reads#ixzz46ar8D7uI  "Russia's activity within the Western Hemisphere has increased since the beginning of the Obama Administration. Russian activity in the Western Hemisphere first began with the sale of military equipment to Venezuela that soon transitioned into the two nations participating in joint naval exercises. It was believed that the Russia decision to launch the exercise came after the U.S. announced it would be reforming the 4th fleet to patrol the Caribbean.
. . . 
"Just a year after the Russian and Venezuelan naval exercise, the U.S. spotted Russian attack submarines patrolling off the coast of the U.S.  . . . it appeared to be part of an effort "to project force around the world, or at least to take excursions around the world." This force projection was a clear message to the U.S. that they are capable to operate anywhere around the world, even in the U.S.'s back yard. "Russian subs were detected operating incredibly close to U.S. data cables in 2015. While data cables near the U.S. coast commonly experience breaking or malfunctions, these cables are fixable within days. The fear from U.S. officials arose if the Russians cut a cable at extreme depths. The damages to these cables are much more difficult to find and fix, which could result in communications and internet access being down for weeks or even months. "In September of 2015, the Russian research vessel, Yantar, sailed into the Caribbean around the same time the U.S. sub the Wyoming docked in Scotland. The Yantar is equipped with cable cutting equipment, but more importantly it is believed to have been conducting anti-submarine warfare operations against U.S. ballistic missile submarines based at Kings Bay, Ga.
. . .
"Aside from expanding its naval presence, Russia has also sought to strengthen its relationships with South American governments. Outside of Venezuela, Russia has entered into discussions about using military bases with Nicaragua and Cuba. The Russian government has also sent military hardware to Argentina, Brazil, Columbia, Peru, and Ecuador. All of these efforts are made to increase Russian influence in the region, and at best turn these nations against the U.S.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Most of this was news to me.  I have been searching for info on this question since it was launched, and this is the first I've found.  I think that Russia/Putin would announce such a naval exercise with a blare of trumpets well in advance; having not heard so much as a piccolo, I am inclined to agree with other forecasters who say that with low oil prices and so many other irons in the fire, Putin has neither the resources nor the time to rattle this saber.   (Sorry about the mixed metaphors.)

No change. Simply coming back w/ justification - for myself -  on a forecast that may prove errant in the hope that I can learn for future reference. Here, as we all know, a navel exercise of the sort asked by this GJ Q takes lots of planning and, time is of the essence w/ less than 90 days remaining for the 1/7/16 resolution.  In addition, definitional Qs arise in what constitute "navel exercises" et cetera. The "fleet of ships"  have to get there. That alone puts the world on notice. Furthermore, there must a detailed co-ordination w/ the particular country involved ( Venezuela, Nicaragua, both highly questionable for various reasons ).  Each of these events taken alone may not create global concern but, when taken together considering the  serious post Crimea geopolitical implications where the world just stood by and watched; a further Russian extension of military conduct would surely bring a  US response of a sort. NB: the timing of this GJ Q comes exactly at this point in time that Putin is trying to get of out the sanctions doghouse and, accumulate brownie point meetings  w/ G7 PM such as the upcoming highly probable Sochi meeting w/ Japan PM Abe in late May and, is looking for an invitation to Tokyo as well.  Thus, every bit of top down sources I can identify  from the Russian sphere shows their naval focus either w/ larger super powers such as China http://nationalinterest.org/blog/the-buzz/watch-out-china-russia-are-working-together-sea-15767  or, from TASS further evidence their Pacific of 28 ships including six Indonesian vessels will conduct mutual exercises. NB: Sputnik also reported on 31/3/16 Putin would be invited by Panamaim President Valera on 26/6/16 to ( I can imagine what most of you are thinking.....reference the recent Panamanian data drops) a dedication to the beginning of construction locks in the Panama Canal.  Beyond this NOSI Navel Open Source Intelligence https://nosi.org/category/russiannavy/
confirms the above mentioned points and, has absolutely no conjecture, or indirect evidence of such an exercise. Ditto Russia & India Report
https://in.rbth.com/tag/russian%20navy Conclusion: In summary, the weight of evidence shows a clear focus on other more critical regions including the Syrian navel port of Tartus which remains a clear focus for Putin. For the time being, I still rate this as above referenced.

Opening assessment based on Rucas_1972's assessment and others. Given the current climate, I think it's unlikely that this will happen. Association with Russia is not really something that any Central or South American state will be courting at the moment, perhaps with the exception of Venezuela. However, the situation there appears to be reaching a crisis point anyway, with political change looking likely to take place.  If Russia had the funds to make association desirable, for example in the soft power style of China in this region, then perhaps things might be different. However, a declining financial position in Russia, coupled with their military commitments closer to home, suggest to me that there's a low probability at this stage of this even occurring.

El embajador saliente de Rusia,Nicolay Vladimir, recibe reconocimiento de la Asamblea Nacional por su trabajo diplomático en Nicaragua LA PRENSA/L.Navas El embajador de Rusia en Nicaragua, Nikolay Mikhaylovich Vladimir, dijo este lunes que su país ha preparado en Nicaragua casi a cuatrocientos oficiales de Centroamérica, Ecuador, República Dominicana y Haití en el centro de capacitación antidrogas que construyen en Managua. “Ya han graduado de 360 a 380 oficiales de países de Centroamérica más Ecuador, (República) Dominicana y Haití”, dijo el diplomático, que recibió este lunes un reconocimiento en el parlamento nicaragüense porque el próximo 11 de febrero concluye su período como embajador. Rusia construye en Las Colinas, en Managua, “un moderno centro de capacitación militar” para militares y policías, donde ya se recibe a personal de diez países de la región para capacitarlos en temas de lucha contra el crimen organizado, dijo el diplomático.
Vladimir anunció que una misión del Gobierno de Nicaragua viajará la próxima semana a Moscú, capital de Rusia, para concretar la ampliación de otro acuerdo de cooperación entre ambos países. Entre los puntos a concretarse en ese encuentro está el financiamiento de parte de los rusos para ampliar la capacidad del nuevo laboratorio de desarrollo de vacunas, que también se construye en Managua.
El objetivo es que se elaboren vacunas contra el dengue, chikungunya y el zika. Rusia ya ha destinado 14 millones de dólares para la construcción del laboratorio de vacunas en Nicaragua.
El embajador Vladimir explicó que ampliar la ayuda en esta área es el acuerdo entre el director del Instituto de Vacunas y Sueros de San Petersburgo, Víctor Trujin, quien hace unas semanas se reunió con el presidente inconstitucional Daniel Ortega. ÁREA MILITAR Vladimir resaltó que la relación bilateral se ha fortalecido en diferentes campos, siendo priorizados el de Salud, Turismo y el apoyo al combate contra el narcotráfico. Agregó que la cooperación rusa con Nicaragua se extiende al ayudar a mejorar el programa de prevención y mitigación de desastres naturales, el cual Rusia financió con 28 millones de dólares en tres años en equipamiento y modernización técnica. Anunció que se negocia que su país financie la construcción de un centro de capacitación para desminado humanitario en Nicaragua. Según Vladimir, este centro permitiría que personal de otros países donde hay conflicto armado, como Colombia, venga a conocer la experiencia en el desminado realizado en Nicaragua.
Vladimir entregó sus cartas credenciales como embajador en febrero de 2012 y concluye oficialmente el 11 de febrero de 2016. Russia faces an already engaged military, economic troubles within its borders, and the lack of useful partners in Latin America. For starters, Russia is engaged in both Syria and Eastern Europe. According to the the principles of realist foreign policy, the actions of the West call for a response from Russia. Putin is all to happy to oblige when possible. With this background, it is perfectly conceivable that Russia would attempt to enhance and extend its power into the Western Hemisphere. 
That said, other commentators produced good numbers regarding the frequency of such exercises, the amount of time until the question closes, and the various  foreign policy crisis being dealt with by Russia, to make the prospect of such an event seem very unlikely. If, all things held constant, the geopolitical situation was less of a mess (Syria, Ukraine, ISIS), then the likelihood of this event would go up by about 10-15% in the near term.  I don't know how far in advance these types of things go from being public to being executed, but I imagine by the end of February, this will be near zero (for the time frame). I'll adjust accordingly as the weeks progress.

Russian military exercises increased 14% in 2015 vs 2014 according to the Russian defense ministry. I estimate that they doubled between 2007 and 2015, based on a 3x nominal increase in defense spending over that period. 
That puts the probability at 9%.  I adjust this by 0.8x to account for Russian interests in seeing European sanctions unwound by the end of H1, and a further 0.8x to account for Cuba's growing proximity to the US, limited Nicaraguan equipment, and Venezuela's dire economic conditions. Unlikely Rationale: Russia is historically a regionally focussed power, and still has concerns around regional border threats which go back centuries (post Frano-Russian War, WW1, WW2, etc). While to modern westerners these threats seem unrealistic - their perception of enemies at the gate from NATO, or other perceived unfriendly nearby states is clearly real to their state, and also serves Putin's political aims. Viewed in this light Russia's continued aggression against any regional states threatening alignment to NATO, or critical military assets leaving the Russian sphere of influence is (and I would have said was)  was predictable. Hence the Russo-Georgian War, the Russian Georgian–Ossetian conflict, Russia-Ukraine conflicts and Annexation of Crimea (containing Sevastopol - home to their Black Sea fleet). While slightly further afield Syria has historically also been a key ally since 1946 - with a key Naval base in Tartus (Russia's only Mediterranean port). Taken in US context - a threat to both the Crimea and Tartus would be perhaps somewhat analogous to a threat against US bases in Guam or Hawai - so in this case its predictable that Russia will go the distance in both conflicts. However triggering new active conflicts in Latin American seems highly unlikely, especially with active conflicts elsewhere and depressed oil prices impact the Russian economy so badly. Cuba is currently drifting outside of Russian sphere of influence - and imho (give the end of the Cold War, MAD and advanced submarine based nuclear missiles) has far less strategic value now to Russia.  US is also moving towards normalising relationship with Cuba, likely to continue (assuming anyone but Neocons Republicans win the next election). Should US reverse this political Cuban detente increased Russian backing is perhaps possible - but only if Cuba feels seriously threatened (which would be counter US best interests, so seems highly unlikely).  Visiting naval ships - most certainly as a PR exercise, but a full naval exercise at this time would seem to be counter-productive to both sides; and needlessly focus international PR and drain limited Russian funds.

It seems to me to be unlikely in the extreme that Russia would be able to devote naval assets to an exercise in Central or South America in the next 6 months.  The flagship of the Pacific Fleet (Varyag) has been deployed to the Mediterranean sea (as of approximately Jan 3 2016), in relief of Russian naval assets (Moskva) supporting their campaign in Syria.  This to me indicates that the operational tempo in the Black and Mediterranean Seas is putting some pressure on the availability of large surface combatant vessels (or that, due to current tensions, Russia is not willing to transfer assets from the Northern Fleet).  In addition, the Russian budget is challenged by low oil prices (not expected to rise significantly in the next 6 months) and higher than normal external deployments (Syria in particular, but also a heightened readiness level along the Baltic states and Ukrainian borders).   The primary candidate nations for such an exercise in the Americas are generally less able to accommodate such an exercise in the next 6 months - Cuba is seeking some form of rapprochement with the US, Venezuela is suffering from low oil prices and a fragile political situation.  Nicaragua has made overtures to Russia lately (including rumored reports that Russian naval assets would 'patrol' the areas offshore of the proposed Nicaraguan canal), however the canal is a notional item at this time and there are still no reports that Nicaragua and Russia have come to agreement (reports mention only 'discussions') on whether basing/visiting arrangements have been finalized. While the articles referenced in the question description are fairly stale (February 2015 and August 2015), GJP questions have an odd way of anticipating future events.  This is worth a couple of probability points.  :) First, who are the likely candidates?  Venezuela, Cuba, and Nicaragua have historically had the closest Russian ties.  However, each of these countries has problems and none of them has a “blue water” navy (or the need for one). Venezuela has suffered due to the drop in global spot oil prices, but has trained with the Russians as recently as 2015.  Therefore, they have the equipment (electronic systems for secured communication) and ships capable of maneuver with the Russians.  I figure they are the most likely, but, since they have just had a training evolution, I don't believe they are too likely. Cuba's economy is weak, but, with relations with the US picking up, they should marginally improve if they can develop tourism.  Cuba will probably not want to provoke a US reaction so close to obtaining better economic ties.  However, their navy is in a good position to train with the Russians. Nicaragua spends very little of their GDP on military items.  (A good reference is the CIA World Factbook: https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook.)  I don't see them as being able to train successfully with the Russian navy.  Contrary to one of the given articles, I think Nicaragua would prefer closer ties to China than to Russia. The long shots are Brazil and Argentina because they have relatively serious naval resources.  The political climate in Brazil is capable of supporting nothing like joint exercises with the Russians.  Argentina is interesting because of the Falkland Island dispute with the UK.  However, I don't see them taking this on either, especially with a new government in place. Then there is Russia itself.  They are engaged with Ukraine, but that has mostly stabilized.  Russia is actively engaged in Syria.  The Russian navy is scheduled for joint exercises in the Far East with China in 2016 (http://sputniknews.com/world/20151024/1029053988/china-russia-joint-naval-drills.html).  The Russians also made an announcement last year of training exercises with North Korea.  While Russia is capable of doing multiple things at the same time, I don't see them as doing an exercise in the western hemisphere at this time due to low ROI. What could change my mind?  1) A date certain announcement from Russia of such an exercise.  2) What would be a seen as a provocative action from the US which demanded a response in the neighborhood of the US.  3) If Venezuela, Cuba or Nicaragua were to politically destabilize and Russian presence would mitigate it and support the current regimes.
